advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert tried to convince computers newcomers that a pocket computer could do the same as a desktop computer...<br><br><font color="#666666"> Now Texas Instruments brings you a cordless compact computer that solves the same sort of problems as the Apple or IBM Personal Computer...<br><br> ...For most personal computer tasks, its 6K RAM and 34K ROM are ample...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Best''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> XEROX RANGE, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>First Newburry brochure cover<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A complete system, including furniture (except chair) for only A$13164.95" Ouch!! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for Victornet, the net for Victor computers, based on Omninet.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JUNE 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil presents its software" <br><br> - S.BASIC programming language<br> - SPG2 accounting / management software<br> - VOLTAIRE word processing</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 1</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #3 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>As harware arguments wasn't sufficient, NothStar tried to promote software compatability and services.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.peekandpoke.org" target="_blank">www.peekandpoke.org</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MITS BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: None, but built-in software :Lotus 1-2-3 (spreadsheet), Memomaker (wordprocessor), Terminal (communication)
computer.description:
The HP-110 was the first laptop computer to offer the power and the possibilities of a desktop. As it was possible to connect a printer and a disk-drive to it, it was a very serious machine in its category, with Lotus 1-2-3 integrated.
This was the good occasion for Hewlet-Packard to introduce a laptop computer when IBM and Apple were not yet on this part of the market. The HP-110 is somehow compatible with its big brother, the HP-150, and can communicate with HP "calculators" like the HP-41c.
Its design looks like the Dulmont Magnum or the Gavilan produced at the same time. The screen can be tilted to accomodate the right angle of vision for the user.
The HP-110 is equiped with a 8086 16-bit CPU which is much more powerful than the 8088 for example used in the HP-150.
One year later, HP presented the Portable Plus with bigger screen, more memory upgrade and the possibility to change the internal ROM software.
______
Rich Wilson comments: The HP-110 and Portable Plus were actually multi-processor computers! I see something on the schematic called a PPU, and its part number seems to be 146?0562. But it's blurry; the ? might be 3 or 8, and the 0 might be an 8. In sleep mode, the 8086 is powered off, and the PPU is given the job of keeping the time, controlling the power supply and charger, monitoring the power button, etc.
computer.keyboard: QWERTY / AZERTY mechanical keyboard75 keys, 8 function keys
computer.language: None, but built-in software :Lotus 1-2-3 (spreadsheet), Memomaker (wordprocessor), Terminal (communication)
computer.name: HP-110
computer.ram: HP-110 : 272 kb (up to 176 kb can be used as a virtual disk)HP-110 Plus : 256 kb, upgradable to 1Mb (896 kb max. for virtual disk)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> THE HP-110 PLUS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-110 plus had a bigger screen (25 lines instead of 16), the possibility to change the internal ROM sotfware, and more memory upgrade. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PARIS-DAKAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-110 was used in the famous Paris-Dakar race...</blockquote>
